channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Epstein Files and the Hidden World of an Unaccountable Elite
item.description: The search continues in the documents for ironclad criminal conduct, but the story of a sexual predator given a free ride by the ruling class has already emerged.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
item.media:description: Redacted documents showing email chains from Jeffrey Epstein released by the Justice Department.

item.title: Goldman Sachs General Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.description: Kathryn Ruemmler, a former top Obama administration lawyer, is out at Goldman Sachs after emails showed a friendship with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein spanning many years.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Maureen Farrell, Lauren Hirsch and Duy Nguyen
item.media:credit: William B. Plowman/NBC
item.media:description: Kathryn Ruemmler, the general counsel at Goldman Sachs, in 2014. She said Thursday that her responsibility “is to put Goldman Sachs’s interests first.”

item.title: Ex-Leader of Norway Charged With Corruption Linked to Epstein
item.description: Thorbjorn Jagland, who briefly led Norway in the 1990s, had been protected by diplomatic immunity that came with his work with the Council of Europe, but that privilege was waived.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Stian Lysberg Solum/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Thorbjorn Jagland, center left, a former prime minister of Norway, in Oslo on Thursday.

item.title: How The Times Is Digging Into Millions of Pages of Epstein Files
item.description: Two dozen journalists. A pile of pages that would reach the top of the Empire State Building. And an effort to find the next revelation in a sprawling case.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Healy, Steve Eder, Andrew Chavez, Kirsten Danis and Dylan Freedman
item.media:credit: U.S. Department of Justice
item.media:description: A photo of Jeffrey Epstein with other faces redacted by the Justice Department.

item.title: Trump Repeals Key Greenhouse Gas Finding, Erasing EPA’s Power to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency rejected the bedrock scientific finding that greenhouse gases threaten human life and well being. It means the agency can no longer regulate them.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Rigorous scientific findings since 2009 have showed that greenhouse gases and global warming are harming public health.

item.title: What to Know About the E.P.A.’s Big Attack on Climate Regulation
item.description: The Trump administration has repealed the scientific determination that underpins the government’s legal authority to combat climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Jenny Kane/Associated Press
item.media:description: E.P.A. administrator Lee Zeldin has claimed that previous administrations used the endangerment finding to justify “trillions of dollars” in regulations on polluting industries and its reversal will help the economy.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Trump Plan to Cut $600 Million in Health Funds
item.description: It is the latest court ruling staving off deep cuts to social services that Democratic-led states say are politically motivated and would harm hundreds of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The $600 million in cuts planned this month include grants to state and local public health departments. The funds are administered through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Intelligence Dispute Centers on Kushner Reference in Intercepted Communication
item.description: A whistle-blower has accused Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, of blocking distribution of a report that Jared Kushner’s name came up in an intercepted communication about Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner during a briefing at the Civil-Military Coordination Center in southern Israel in October, while on a trip with Vice President JD Vance.

item.title: DHS Shutdown Nears as Immigration Enforcement Talks Stall
item.description: Senate Democrats refused to move ahead with a spending bill needed to keep the Department of Homeland Security running because it lacked limits they have demanded on federal immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Charges Against Man Shot by ICE
item.description: The top federal prosecutor in Minnesota asked a judge to drop charges against the immigrant who was shot by an ICE agent, saying new evidence was “materially inconsistent” with what officials had claimed.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters near the site of the shooting in Minneapolis.

item.title: The High-Stakes Fight Over Masked Federal Agents
item.description: The debate over whether federal agents should be allowed to cover their faces with masks has become a flashpoint as the government heads for a partial shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: A masked Customs and Border Protection agent during an arrest in Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Guard Troops Fully Withdraw From Chicago, Portland and Los Angeles
item.description: President Trump initially deployed the troops in those cities to support law enforcement efforts to tamp down protests against immigration raids and protecting buildings.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard at their temporary barracks at the U.S. Army Reserve Training Center in Elwood, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, in October.

item.title: N.Y.C. Officials Reinstate Pride Flag at Stonewall After Federal Removal
item.description: Hundreds of people attended a rally on Thursday to re-raise the flag, setting up a defiant response to the Trump administration’s assault on diversity initiatives.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Cristina Matuozzi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Days after the Pride flag was removed from the Stonewall National Monument in Manhattan, federal employees raised an American flag in its place. By Thursday evening, both flags were waving side by side.

item.title: Canada School Shooter’s Online Life Showed Interest in Violent Extremism
item.description: The suspect in the British Columbia shooting had long been posting about mental health problems, substance abuse and a fascination with weapons and online violence.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Aric Toler, Pranav Baskar, Malachy Browne, Amy Harmon and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family home where the authorities say Jesse Van Rootselaar killed her mother, Jennifer Jacobs, and her brother, Emmett Jacobs.

item.title: What We Know About the Victims of the Tumbler Ridge Mass Shooting in Canada
item.description: The attack at a secondary school and a private residence in the small, remote community in British Columbia has left families stunned and grief-stricken.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

item.title: Americans Are Paying the Bill for Tariffs, Despite Trump’s Claims
item.description: Research from the New York Fed confirms that U.S. companies and consumers are bearing tariff costs, despite the president’s assertions otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Sydney Ember
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. companies and consumers are paying most of the cost of tariffs, in the form of higher prices.

item.title: On Trump’s Tariffs, Supreme Court Hurries Up and Waits
item.description: The justices put the case on a fast track at the administration’s urging. But they don’t seem in a rush to rule on the president’s signature economic program.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The next scheduled day for the announcement of Supreme Court decisions is Feb. 20.

item.title: Closing of El Paso Airspace Adds to Tension Between F.A.A. and Pentagon
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration is charged with flight safety, and the Defense Department with national security. Those missions keep colliding.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly, Karoun Demirjian and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: A passenger carried his suitcase at El Paso International Airport after the F.A.A. lifted its temporary closure of the airspace over El Paso.

item.title: El Paso Incident Highlights Gaps in America’s Drone Defense Industry
item.description: The U.S. has spent billions of dollars developing counter-drone technology, but much of it needs more testing in the real world.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for a New American Security
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Many flights at El Paso International Airport were canceled on Wednesday, when the Federal Aviation Administration shut down air traffic there for hours.

item.title: Do Drug Cartels Actually Use Drones at the Border?
item.description: U.S. officials warn that cartel-operated drones on the border pose a major threat. Mexican officials are less certain. Analysts say the answer is likely in between.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: The border wall between Mexico and the United States in Tijuana, Mexico.

item.title: C.I.A. Video Appeals to Potential Spies in China’s Military
item.description: The agency is seeking Chinese officials who are frustrated with corruption in the People’s Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the People’s Liberation Army attending a ceremony in December. Corruption in China’s military has hampered its push to modernize and improve capabilities.

item.title: Alcohol’s Effects on the Body: What Does Drinking Do to Your Health?
item.description: From the moment you take a sip, drinking starts to influence your biology. Here’s an inside look.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith and Montse Galbany

item.title: Greg Brown, Guitarist Who Wrote Cake’s Biggest Hit, Dies at 56
item.description: His song “The Distance,” released in 1996, became an anthem for the disaffected members of Generation X.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: John Atashian/Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Brown in 1996. He left Cake after “Fashion Nugget,” partly over differences with the lead singer, John McCrea.

item.title: Stop the Illegal Transfer of ISIS Suspects
item.description: The U.S. is sending thousands of men accused of belonging to the Islamic State from Syria to Iraq, where they face potential mistreatment.
item.dc:creator: Letta Tayler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: It Is Decision Time for NATO in Munich
item.description: The U.S. and Europe can save the trans-Atlantic alliance. They probably won’t.
item.dc:creator: Michael B.G. Froman

item.title: ‘The Daily Show’ Gives President Trump Yet Another Inaugural Award
item.description: Jordan Klepper congratulated the president, the sole nominee for “the Inaugural Award for Winning the Most Inaugural Awards.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Japan Seizes Chinese Fishing Boat; Move Likely to Add to Tensions
item.description: The seizure of the trawler, which Japan said was sailing in its waters in the East China Sea, is likely to add to tensions between Tokyo and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Japan's Fisheries Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by Japan’s Fisheries Agency shows a Japanese patrol vessel, left, and a Chinese fishing boat off the coast of Nagasaki on Thursday.

item.title: Republicans Ask Supreme Court to Intervene in N.Y. Redistricting Case
item.description: Lawyers for Representative Nicole Malliotakis, Republican of New York, asked the Supreme Court to block a ruling that would redraw her district lines.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford and Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Nicole Malliotakis’s lawyers have asked the Supreme Court to weigh in on a lower-court ruling that found that her district lines were unconstitutional.

item.title: Strong Storm Is Forecast to Hit the South This Weekend With a Risk of Heavy Rain
item.description: It’s finally warming up, which means the storm will most likely bring rain instead of more dreaded ice. But forecasters warned that there may be a lot of it.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Terra Fondriest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rain is likely to hit Arkansas, along with other parts of the South.
